direction.raw_text: : A howling dust storm battering the doors and walls of a tiny woodplank church. Inside, huddled together against the rage outside, are a small group of people. All in black, mostly elderly, they kneel in prayer. Before them, on the cramped altar, lies a man. Dressed in the uniform of a general, surrounded by the silk softness of his casket. He's an old man, far from the crump of battles, consumed now with stillness, listening to the prayers of old people. Of desert wind, moaning through thin wood. The candle beside his head flickers and wanes in the ceaseless gusts, strains for life, then goes out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not the best part of town and probably never was. A place of seedy, anonymous brick flophouses shackled by rusting fire escapes, lying on an alley unique only for its bad drainage. It's here, in the dim, flinty light, that a figure enters. Wearing a long coat and, despite the night, sunglasses, he pauses on the slimy asphalt and gazes up the sides of the flophouses, to their yellowish windows and competing Mexican radio stations. One window, dark and quiet on the third floor, catches his gaze. There's a metal hand railing in the alley that the long-coated figure effortlessly pops up onto. Sunglasses focused on the window, he lowers himself into a motionless crouch, a perch, on the railing with the ease of a crow. Or a gargoyle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Dawn is a muddled, limp thing that does nothing to improve the alley. The figure is still there, a motionless gargoyle perched on the railing. Watching the window. The shadows shorten, the air grows warmer, and now there's movement behind the window. The sunglassed gargoyle drops down off the railing, jumps up to the first rung of the fire escape, and begins climbing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is a room as grim as we expect. Lumpy iron bed, sink that's been pissed into one too many times, and SIMON; a man in a tight sweater and dark sunglasses, busily emptying his pockets on the ruined dresser: loose change, a town paper's obituary column. Simon's sunglassed eyes look up suddenly, his body stifffening. He whips around to face the window just as it EXPLODES into fragments. The gargoyle LEAPS into the room on the trail of glass. Simon spins and THROWS himself against the intruder. The two STRUGGLE savagely across the room, SMASHING chairs. Simon manages a grip on the gargoyle's face and POUNDS the back of his skull against the wall. The gargoyle gets his locked fists up and SWINGS them like a war club, SMACKING Simon's face and SPRAWLING him backwards onto the bed. The two, across the room for each other, pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon's climbed to his feet, the two men in sunglasses now walking slow circles around each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The gargoyle drops his head and DRIVES himself into Simon, who HAMMERS the gargoyle with his fists. Blood SMEARS. The gargoyle's gotten free a knife that he JAMS into Simon's leg. Pressing home his advantage, the gargoyle SLAMS Simon up against the wall. He TEARS open Simon's shirt, digging his fingers into the chest, RIPPING the skin aside, the first plunging deep, CRACKING the sternum bone, pushing even further, toward the blood gouged pumping beneath -- -- Simon PLOWS his knee up between the gargoyle's legs. Over and over. Till the grip loosens and Simon SHOVES him to one side, using the momentum and drives to SWING the body around and at the shattered window. The gargoyle SMACKS the frame and COLLAPSES, his head CRACKING on the sill and FORCING a shard of glass through his neck. Simon moves to the window and brushes aside the gargoyle's sunglasses, revealing two totally empty eye sockets. Pushing his thumbs into them, Simon uses the leverage to lift the gargoyle off the sill and push his body out the window. The gargoyle bounces once on the fire escape, then spread- eagles thirty feet to the asphalt. Somebody turns up their Mexican radio station. The gargoyle's a wreck. But he manages, slowly -- his shattered remains arguing every inch -- to climb first to his knees, then miserably to his feet. A bent, splattered, hopeless thing that manages to stumble three or four feet before being HIT by a freeway- speed firebird BOMBING down the alley. The impact PINS the gargoyle to the grill and RAMS him into a brick wall, CRUSHING a chest that BELCHES out a sickly, bruised heart like a wet rag against the firebird's windshield.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Leave me alone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've found it, haven't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fuck you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Simon leans against his splintered window and looks down at the pinned and very finished body of the gargoyle. His own shirt and pants are a mess of torn blood and his breathing is difficult. Pain flashes across his forehead as he checks that his own sunglasses still sit snugly on the bridge of his nose. At the sound of a distant siren Simon turns and quickly finishes packing his duffle bag. Stiffly pulling on an oversize surplus army jacket that partly conceals the damage beneath, he picks up the bag and painfully shuffles out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : The gargoyle, still pinned to the wall by the firebird.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: bounces off his skin. Then another. He's being photographed. Go wide and find him in the middle of a police investigation. Bored blue uniforms, yellow barrier tape. The usual. A plain jane sedan pulls up and deposits THOMAS DAGGET, thirties, tweed coat and steel notebook. He smiles at a couple of cops, ducks under the yellow barrier, and nods a greeting to an older uniform sergeant, BURROWS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas takes a deep, healthy breath. Burrows just stares at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He eyes finally make their way to the gargoyle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Burrows nods in the direction of a very shook up young man sitting on the curb.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey.

dialogue.raw_text: Hey.

dialogue.raw_text: (looks up at sky) Thought those clouds this morning spelled rain for sure, but it's turned into a beautiful day, wouldn't you say, Sergeant Burrows?

dialogue.raw_text: We've found everything else -- and what fun that was, let me tell you -- but the eyes are still AWOL. Might just be stuck in the radiator grill. Little weird though.

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Both popping out together like that. Worth a page in my scrapbook.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Burrows and Thomas coming up the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They enter the room, which is, of course, totally trashed. Thomas steps over the splintered furniture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas looks at the splashes of blood, overturned dressers, a newspaper, the "Chimney Rock Republican"; one name in its obit section circled. Burrows sighs and checks his watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amongst the glass fragments at Thomas' feet is a pair of dark sunglasses. He picks them up, taps them in his palm, and looks out the window down to the man with no eyes, pinched between brick and chrome.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : The sun sinking beneath the horizon of a vast and undulating expanse of desert. Travel through the landscape as the sky purples and darkens and silhouettes tall, finger-like spires of volcanic rock. Hear the coyotes, the wind making its constant, probing search. Before the night swallows it all whole, Come upon The Town. It used to be something. But that's long gone. Now, wrapped in the sucking blackness of a wilderness night, it's a shell of a place. Lights still burn in some of the windows but fool no one. The ghosts are the majority here. Biding their time. Waiting for The Town to surrender and slip beneath the waves of the desert. The wind slinks over the hills, creeps down past boarded-up storefronts, skeletal ocitillo, and the rusting hulks of abandoned mining equipment. The corpse of a summer's kite twists slowly on a power line.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Who's the room registered under?

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ku San's on fourteenth is still open for another hour. Whatd'ya say we pull out the 'ol "SUICIDE" rubber stamp and get some lunch. Rancid chow mein and watered beer for under three bucks.

direction.raw_text: From the inky oblivion of the road, comes a crunch of gravel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stands a large, nineteenth century brick schoolhouse. An icon from a more prosperous past, its dark massiveness was meant for scores of ruddy-faced miner's kids. Now it seems to be imploding, eating itself with creeping decay. On this night it is silent and dark but for a small glow in one corner and the faint sound of children's voices in song. It is a hymn. An ancient, Latin one. The melancholy beauty of voices rising and falling in choir.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: ON THE OTHER SIDE OF TOWN

direction.raw_text: Is a school auditorium. On the stage, dwarfed by it, are twenty five students from first grade to high school, singing together as a choir. A young woman, KATHERINE, directs their acapella voices as the small group of parents, lonely in the huge room, look on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The voices drift on the night, down the road, and lap against the peeling facade of a storefront. A mortuary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The rooms are dark but for one. There, bathed in the flickering light of a tall candle, lies the body of the old general we saw at the opening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of the mortuary has a locked handle that jiggles from outside. A small panes of glass beside it is BROKEN by a hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Young voices struggle with the complicated hymn and its pain of centuries. Faces white, Mexican, Navaho. Katherine guides them with soft hands. She smiles in pride. They smile back. Proud. Of her. Of themselves and the beauty coming from their mouths. One small, beautiful navaho girl, MARY, maybe eight, gets a special smile of special friendship from Katherine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Front door now stands ajar in the darkness. Small shards of glass glisten in the carpet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is the dead General. Even in the bleached ravages of age and death, his face still holds a shadow of vigor and pride. It takes a moment in the weak flicker of the candle to realize someone is there with him. Simon in his oversized surplus jacket. His arms are folded tightly across his middle, as if in deep cold. But his gaunt face is moist with sweat and his breath is shallow and uneven. He stares at the old man behind sunglasses and takes slow, cautious steps forward into the amber glow. Holding out two blood-stained fingers, Simon touches the General's forehead. A new strain crosses his perspiring face. Concentration. Placing his right palm on the General's chin and the left on his forehead, Simon CRACKS OPEN the dead man's mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The hymn is reaching its aching climax of medieval longing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon leans down to the open mouth, and in a voice soft and deeply weary,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then, with the school choir distant and faint in the night, the living man places his mouth over that of the dead man...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Qui ex Patre Flioque procedit...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It's coffee and cake now as parents proudly hug their children and congratulate their young teacher. Even in this gloomy, crumbling building it's a warm, small town moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon has left the mortuary and now limps with difficulty through the silent streets, leaning against shop walls for support.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Through the doors out steps the eight year old Navaho girl, Mary. Alone, she stands on the stone stairs and looks out into the night with sensitive eyes. She concentrates. Knows. Katherine follows her out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The girl's eyes seem too serious for a child's. Too perceptive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Katherine looks out into the night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary stares a moment longer, then becomes a child again, smiling and popping Katherine one on the arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary suddenly points past Katherine's shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When Katherine turns Mary dashes back into the building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Katherine chases after her.

direction.raw_text: Simon comes limping up from the road. His breathing's bad now as he moves stiffly along the school's brick walls, coming to an old, rusty back door he creaks open and slides through.

direction.raw_text: He climbs a littered and disused staircase, past broken beer bottles and condom wrappers to a dark and creaky second floor. It's part of the school building long abandoned. Doors to classrooms lie half off their hinges, windows are broken, rats squeak between ancient desks stacked like funeral pyres. Simon, his breath echoing in the cold darkness, shuffles along the broken linoleum till he comes to a rectangle cut in the wall where a row of lockers used to be. He crawls into the space and there, surrounded by rot, curls up on himself and sucks his thumb.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas Dagget's eyes opening slowly. He sits up in his bed, runs a hand through his hair, and looks out with only medium enthusiasm at the morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas lights an offering candle and kneels for a brief, silent prayer. He crosses himself, stands, and walks for the door. Before leaving he glances back at the altar. A questioning moment between two akward, estranged friends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas sits at his desk half-heartily trying to make sense of the three dozen files piled there. Lt. Paul, his boss, leans against a wall nearby.

dialogue.raw_text: When babies grow up their bones get larger by adding calcium layers over the interior haversham canals. Child growth isn't uniform though, comes in spurts that always leave growth rings in the bone. Everybody has them -- except your man. That would, to a hasty observer, seem to indicate he had never been a child.

direction.raw_text: Thomas at his desk, working under a lone gooseneck lamp. He's translating the fourteenth chapter of St. John's Revelations from Latin onto a slip of paper. Finished, he sets the ancient bible down, turns off the gooseneck, and leans back in his chair, alone in the dark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here, outside The Town, horizons are distant, faraway things. The sky overhead is streaked red and blue with barely morning as the screen door of a simple stucco house swings open. It's Katherine, the teacher. Wearing levis and boots, she carries a saddle swung over one denim shoulder out to a corral behind the house where a horse shuffles and whinnies impatiently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Katherine throws the saddle over the horse and cinches it down as the sun, still tucked behind pink and grey cliffs, begins to heat up the sky.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: In a minute, in a minute...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Deep and narrow, an idyllic canyon of compressed sandstone walls smoothed, rounded and etched by centuries of wind. A tiny creek flows past weak banks of scrub pine and pocked sycamore. A silent place a long way and a long time from anything but the approach of galloping hooves. Katherine and her horse run full-out through the canyon, the clack and splash of hooves echoing off steep, shadowed walls. Horse and rider drive each other harder and harder, their hot breath brief clouds in the arch, thin desert air. Boulders shattered by winter cold and summer heat, deep wind- cut caves hiding scorpions, sidewinders, or a wary mountain lion all pass as in a blur; arrogant hawks and patient buzzards, ruins of thousand year old Anasazi villages high on the cliffs, their weather-beaten skulls, seen and unseen, staring out; everything is one smear of color and smell as Katherine gallops past them and up the cliff trail, out of the canyon, and onto the main plateau.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Katherine strokes her horse and feeds it a bag of carrots. She pulls a thermos from the pack, sits down against some old man rocks, and with the coffee steaming in her hand, greets the sun now cresting the Chuska Mountains. There's a rutted, silty dirt road nearby. An ancient, battered school bus rattles its way past and stops. The bus driver, a Navaho, JOHN, climbs down and rubbing the side of his head painfully walks up to Katherine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He holds out an empty cup Katherine fills. Sipping painfully, he lays down beside her and pulls the brim of his baseball cap over his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bus is full of young school kids.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Katherine's horse snorts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He finishes the coffee and climbs painfully to his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He shuffles back to the bus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bus coughs alive and crawls forward. Katherine waves to the faces behind glass, then settles back for a last moment of peace as silence lays again over the land.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Try growing up here. (tries word out on tongue) Ox-nard. (sticks out coffee cup) Uno mas, see-boo-play. (she pours) Speaking of romantic pale faces, the rumor mill is in high gear again.

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks for the joe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No prob.

dialogue.raw_text: All right children, looks sharp! This is a school day! And no talking loud!

direction.raw_text: Showered and changed into her teaching clothes, Katherine climbs into a rattling pickup.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Katherine drives to work, passing on the outskirts the closed copper mine, vast and abandoned. Down beyond the fading main street lies the great crumbling brick pile that is the school. Katherine parks her truck, grabs her leather bag, and walks in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Katherine's lecturing her students. All twenty-five of them. There's high school age sons of white ranchers, Navaho girls on the edge of puberty, tiny Mexican children. All being taught together in one room. It's dinosaur day. Katherine has a large fossilized bone on her lap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The little girls smile. They like Camposaurus. Katherine holds up another bone fragment.

dialogue.raw_text: More than a little. They're the best. Sixth century. Hand illuminated. Vichini only did twenty, each pocket size for a king to carry into battle beside his heart. Some consider them the finest bibles ever made. I thought they'd all be in museums. What are you doing with it?

dialogue.raw_text: (reading from slip of paper) "And as in the first war, the angels so fought over the nature of their God, and there was much vanity and destruction in heaven. For some angels called their Lord the son of God, and others called Him the begotten father of Jesus Christ." What do you think?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've never heard that quote before. Theologically, The "first war" obviously refers to the war in heaven where Michael the archangel threw out Satan and his gang. Old time bible stuff. But this implies there was a second war. That's news to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And the rest of it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, it's a fairly common theological debate. Or was. The idea that if Christ is God's son, does that make him less than God or are they the same being in different forms. That very argument almost tore the early Christian church apart in the 4th Century. That was the good old days when people actually worried about theology. Anyway, it was settled when the bishops of the world got to together at the Council of Nicene in 325 and hashed out the various interpretations of scripture into a uniform dogma of belief. The result was the Nicene Creed, which basically said that Christ was in fact the same as God and was owed the same power and respect as the Father. That they were the same. (smiles) But it's not exactly the sort of thing angels would fight over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, they could just ask God, right?

dialogue.raw_text: Who knows? Vichini was the greatest biblical scholar of the age, some claimed he made his own translations from the original writings. Maybe he did find some unknown writings by John. It's possible I suppose. John always was a little negative about angels. All this actually has something to do with an LAPD murder?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know yet. Maybe. Probably not.

dialogue.raw_text: I hate to break it you, but that particular family spat has been settled for 1,600 years. Nobody loses sleep over it anymore. Honest.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, he didn't trust them much. All that running around smiting and killing in the name of the Lord. God's wild bunch. He thought it made them fickle and vain. One click above ghosts. Satan didn't help the image much either.

direction.raw_text: The building is squat and brick. A non-descrip warehouse that subs as a police evidence storage area. The sun is hard today as it beats down on Jerry's large- brimmed felt hat. Daylight and Jerry don't get along very well. His sunken, filmy eyes squint at its glare. The decayed flesh cracking along his cheeks flames at its touch. He shuffles down the sidewalk, the brackish, amber fluid that gurgles down his leg filling his shoes and leaving behind shiny wet footprints like a snail. There's nobody around the back door and its unlocked. Jerry's shrunken claws pull it open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is a crush of filing cabinets and erector-set shelves. All of it crammed with low grade stuff. The heroin busts and million dollar currency arrests don't end up here. Here it's all shoe boxes and dusty files. Fragments of small lives forgotten. Jerry pulls the brim of his hat down even further as he works his way past rack after rack. The single uniform he meets looks only casually at Jerry's lapel ID badge. It's on the third shelf he finds it. John Doe #78. Jerry lifts the box and walks out.

direction.raw_text: Tiled floor and refrigerated corpses. Nobody's around when Gabriel enters. He walks over to a file cabinet and removes a thick folder. Then he walks to the big filing cabinets, the ones that hold a body in each drawer. He strolls along, tapping each label till he finds the one he's looking for, slides it open, and looks down at the naked body of the gargoyle. He's been sewed back together. Kind of. Gabriel grabs the eyeless corpse under the armpits and drags him out onto the floor where he pushes the legs together and outstretches the arms, like a crucifix. From his coat Gabriel takes out a small vial of oil and rubs it onto the gargoyle's feet and hands. Anointing them. Then with the tip of his finger, he draws a faint sign of the cross on the forehead, stands, and walks for the door. In the background, as Gabriel leaves, we see the body of the gargoyle BURST into flame.

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter, pumpkin? Did you eat something? (concerned beat) Did he give you something?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can I go home now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, hon. Let's go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Katherine drives Mary home, a dusty, tired mobile home slumped among the saguaro and tumbleweed on the edge of town.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MOBILE HOME Mary and Katherine pull open the door and enter. Mary's elderly grandmother is sitting watching "All My Children". She smiles at Katherine and looks at Mary with concern as the little girl rubs her stomach and explains something in Navaho.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Katherine helps tuck Mary in bed as her grandmother brings a glass of water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The grandmother sits beside Mary, whispers gently in Navaho, and softly stokes her brow.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'll have the school send over a doctor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (on the phone) ...He's was just laying up there. I thought, with the kids and everything...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Most of my boys are up the highway on a tanker spill at the moment. They may be a while. These people are rarely any problem. I'll have a deputy come by tonight or tomorrow and shoo him out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He looked hurt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They all do, ma'am. Inside or out, they're all damaged goods.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Alone and tucked into bed, Mary stares off at something very, very far away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sun orange and fading outside his window, Thomas drifts off into a nap on his couch. The phone rings.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's your friendly coroner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why is my friendly coroner, after a long day at work, calling me at home?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have something you'll want to see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I doubt it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, you'll definitely want to see this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: On the floor is the smoldering, blackened outline of a body. A thick, slimy goo gurgles and pops. The whole room is afoul with acrid smoke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas jams his hands in his pockets and leans against an autopsy table. Watches the smoke curl slowly up from the impossibly melted goo in front of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas pulls out out his notebook.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: They also took the autopsy file.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: "They"?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He, she, it. They took it. They also lifted all the physical evidence from the San Julian impound.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where was everyone?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The cop at the desk is in the hospital as we speak with a broken collarbone. Everyone else was down the hall watching the basketball playoffs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who won?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Temple.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lucky.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. Foul on the buzzer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Looks like the snow angels we used to make as kids. Lie down in a clean bank. Move your arms up and down...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know what this means. Our friend's cleaned out all the evidence on this guy. Everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did the cop get a look at who nailed him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tall. Smiled a lot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anything else?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He wore sunglasses.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You gonna figure this one out, Tom?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going to try.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When you do, give me a call. Tell me I'm not crazy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Gabriel crouches on the linoleum and pours everything out of the evidence box onto the floor. He sifts through it, a smile appearing when comes across the Chimney Rock Republican and its circled obituary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jerry is looking worse by the day. A rotting, oozing fissure has opened on his forehead. His right eye doesn't move anymore. He sits on a kitchen chair glumly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You like the desert, Jerry?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You promised. You promised that -- GABRIEL -- Soon. Honest. Don't be a pest about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sighs) Never trust a fucking angel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excellent advice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Thomas sits hunched over his notes from the first day of the investigation. Written in it is the Chimney Rock Republican and the obituary name of General Arnold Hawthorn. Lt. Paul sits down in the chair opposite.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas slowly closes his notebook.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Lt. rubs his eyes tiredly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . PAUL Do you ever have one of those afternoons where you feel no one's giving you a straight answer about anything?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, maybe five or six times a week.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . PAUL (reading sheet) It says here somebody got into the property warehouse and cleaned everything out of your evidence box. No, he did leave one thing. A footprint. 11-D.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mud on his shoes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . PAUL Spinal fluid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . PAUL I'm not going to get a straight answer out of you either, am I?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I need to go to Arizona.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . PAUL For your health?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So I can give you a straight answer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . PAUL Sure, why not? Take the kids. See the Grand Canyon. Send me a fucking postcard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . PAUL I've got a headache, Tom, and I hate my life. If you have to go, go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: On an utterly lonely blacktop, Gabriel shoots by in his top- down rambler, insignificant in the night's vastness. Jerry's in the back, feet up on the seat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabriel suddenly stands on the brakes, SCREECHING the rambler to a dusty stop. He kills the engine and everything is instantly whispering night and coyote howls. Gabriel climbs out and walks to the edge of a cliff. Far below, nestled among the finger-like spires of volcanic cones, lies The Town. Twinkling lights in a cold, dark embrace. Gabriel pushes his sunglasses up his nose and smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two coyotes begin fighting and snarling with each other in the dust nearby.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Why do you need me? I can hardly walk now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Some things are human work, son. Live or dead, human work. Besides, I like you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lucky moi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can always smell a graveyard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: On a low hill at the edge of town. Cracked, sinking headstones. The rambler's parked next to a new one, Slim Pickens on the AM, as Jerry digs up the fresh grave marked General Arnold Hawthorne. Gabriel sits perched on the headstone over the grave like a winged creature.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jerry's shovel CLANKS onto something hard. He scrapes away the dirt, revealing a coffin lid. With a socket wrench Jerry removes the fastening bolts, then with the edge of his shovel, pries open the lid. It's the ancient, wasted general we saw at the beginning. His medals flash in the moonlight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabriel leaps off his perch down into the grave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabriel reaches down, places one hand on the General's forehead, one on his chin, and BREAKS the mouth open. He gazes down into it. Then suddenly stiffens and straightens up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabriel frantically look in the ears. Up the nose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabriel BANGS the coffin lid in frustration. Tries to think.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I hope you're enjoying this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I always enjoy watching you work, Jerry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How did I ever get you in my life?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, you didn't really want to kill yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I did it, didn't I? I did kill myself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, yes. Technically.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And you're just keeping me alive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Letting you die slower.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm so in your debt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, Jerry. I'm touched. Really.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not much to look at.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, but it's not what's on the outside that matters --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's what's on the inside.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (upset) It's not here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oooh, bad news for the war effort.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (spins wildly on him) Shut up!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now, if you were a soul, where would you hide?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The hell away from you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The numbers on the clock radio roll over five AM and the news comes on. Thomas stirs in bed, rubs his eyes, and looks out at a sky untouched by any sign of dawn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : In coat and tie, Thomas sits in his spartan kitchen stirring a coffee when the phone rings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas looks up at his overnight bag, sitting half-packed on the dresser.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He cradles the phone, stares at it, then picks up his overnight bag.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey little brother.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiles) Hey. How's the world?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The world's the usual. Except for a guppy. the world's minus one guppy this morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And Jamie and Mac?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They keep asking for Uncle Tommy. The only man that can make stuffed bears talk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My one true calling. What's up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's five-thirty in the morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beat) I just thought I should call.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You always were telepathic.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's my job, Jan. I go places sometimes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I just had this terrible feeling about it. What's happening, Tom?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I miss you. Even when you're here. I miss you. I miss my brother. It's been four years, Tom, since...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're the only blood family we have left, you and me. I worry about you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll be okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry about the dawn-attack call. I love you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I love you too, Jan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Silent and dead at this hour. Gabriel's boots creak on the floorboards of the 19th century plank sidewalks. He taps his finger aimlessly along plate glass shop windows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jerry, limping on a foot that's caving in on itself, wiping the spinal fluid out of his dead eye, shuffles along behind. Gabriel pops off the elevated sidewalk, grabs a parking meter and swings himself playfully around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabriel suddenly freezes. He sticks his nose up, sniffs like a coyote, then abruptly drops to the ground in a push-up and smells the dirt. Tastes it with his tongue. Smiles.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Boy, what a dump, huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why can't this shit ever go down in Miami? Or Bora Bora? I feel like I've spent my whole damn stay in gin swills like this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Life's a bitch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well well...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A fracture of broken moon tumbles through shattered windows and falls dully across shapes old, shapes forgotten, and one shape trying hopelessly to drag itself across the floor. It's Simon; breath a rasp, blood-soaked pants leaving a long smear behind him like a hemorrhaging snail. He coughs, drags an arm across the lenses of his sunglasses, And looks up at a pair of black, lizard-skin boots.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon rolls on his back and sighs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon looks up at puss-faced Jerry, leaning quietly in a dark corner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabriel sits down against the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabriel turns his boot to the moon, watches the pale light glint back off the lizard scales.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon suddenly JUMPS to his feet. Tries to escape. Jerry trips him, SPRAWLING Simon back to the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabriel walks over to him. Puts his face close.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon doesn't answer. Gabriel shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabriel pauses, almost thoughtfully. Then he smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabriel grasps Simon's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabriel's hand is suddenly on Simon's face, fingers spread, claw-like. They press into the flesh. Hard. And harder. Until Simon starts to bleed. Then to burn.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hi, Simon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gabriel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't mind me. Just along for the ride.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So, what shall we talk about? Theology?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm a little talked out on theology.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fair enough...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know why I'm here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't happen to have it on you by chance?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That would have been too easy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, Simon. Get serious.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now. Where's the soul? (beat) You know. So high. Used to reside in the recently departed General Hawthorne.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have it your way, big guy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I do have one question.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shoot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you even remember what this war's about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's hardly the point, is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess I never did get the point.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Happens.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do you do it, Gabriel? How do you go on and on in this place?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I like it here, Simon. I always have.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm so tired...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then join us, Simon. Reject the Nicene Council. We were here first.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't do it, Gabriel. I don't even know why anymore, but I can't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know the routine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (swallows hard) Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Katherine startles abruptly in her bed at the faraway sound of Simon's screams. Screams carried either on the wind or her dreams.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Asleep, sweaty, shivering, Mary suddenly opens her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabriel releases his grip on Simon, letting him fall back against the wall, afire. His clothes twist and blacken. His skin creeps and pops. His sunglasses melt and fall away; revealing two hollow pits beneath. Gabriel lifts Simon's entire body up off the floor by just the disintegrating face, and stares into the hollow pits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the fires go out. Gabriel drops the crackling, acrid body onto the floor. Impossibly, through the sizzling mucus and molten hair, it breathes. It gasps in pain. It won't die.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Not yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can do this for five months, Simon...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The skies above lighten and smear blue and red.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Finishes dressing for school, picks up her teaching bag, and crunches out across the gravel to her pick-up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabriel's lizard boots pace back and forth past Simon's writhing, burning body. Gabriel's more jittery now. Losing his patience. He bends down and pulls Simon's face up to his.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The seared skin around Simon's mouth comes off in Gabriel's hand. But Simon is still, even now, silent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He flings Simon with a horrible crunch against the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks over and places a hand with something like friendship on Simon's charred shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And with the other hand Gabriel JAMS his fist into Simon's chest, PULLING OUT a lumpy, burned heart. Simon's mouth springs open and hisses emptily. Gabriel slips the heart into his pocket and lets go of Simon's shoulder. The body instantly disintegrates and crashes to the floor.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This is getting boring, Simon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Amen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where is it? Where did you put it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where is it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm just about out of tricks here. You're a tough one, friend. Old school.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: God loves you, Simon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Katherine squints at the morning glare as she drives through town. Pulling into the school's drive she sees, parked at the building's back door, a sheriff's patrol car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Katherine comes up the stairs of the building's abandoned floor, passing the stacks of rotting desks toward where she last saw Simon. There's a bad smell in the air. At a turn stands a deputy that looks up as Katherine approaches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Katherine looks past him to where a second deputy crouches down beside... beside something. It's human shaped, but like a shadow. A shadow twisted in agony and slicked with a tarry, smoldering ooze. The smell is overpowering. The crouched deputy has a handkerchief over his mouth.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You may want to skip this, ma'am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: God damn...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Katherine) Were any of your students up here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mary...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Katherine pulls-up and parks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary is still in bed, droopy-eyed and sweating. Her grandmother is there, and so is an elderly Navaho. He stands beside Mary's side, holding above her body a clenched pouch that he passes slowly back and forth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The old man mumbles a soft chant as he moves the pouch back and forth across Mary's body.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to grandmother) How is she?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Same.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did the doctor come by?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He found nothing. But something is in her. I know. Something the Belagaana doctor can't see. The night people have been around two days now. It is a warning. (nods to Navaho man) So we have called the hand trembler. To find if she must have an Enemy Ghost Way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Katherine walks back out toward her pickup. She stops. Thirty yards away, almost invisible in the sage say for the glare of its evil, intelligent eyes, is a coyote. As she feels it's gaze a shadow suddenly crosses her shoulder. Katherine turns quickly but only barely catches, out of the corner of her eye, a glimpse of something very large. And winged.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : A huge semi ROARING deafeningly past on an empty desert highway, KICKING UP a dusty cyclone that drifts over a one- horse gas station and Thomas, sitting there in his car checking a map. CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Small townish; old adobe and stucco walls, cannon on the front lawn, every door loudly declaring itself a department: SOCIAL SERVICES, COURTS, and, SHERIFF.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Sheriff's personal office is turn of the century regal, with high beam ceilings and rotating fans. Nothing seems newer than 1940, including the coffee pot the Sheriff pours a mugful from. Trim with glasses, bolo tie and boots, he looks like Barry Goldwater.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hands the coffee to Thomas, sitting in a chair beside his solid oak desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Sheriff smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She hands them to the Sheriff, who passes them on to Thomas. He flips through the stack, comes up with nothing. The secretary hands another, single sheet to the Sheriff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas perks at The Town's name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Sheriff's brow crinkles in consternation as he reads further.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Sheriff hands it to him. Glancing at it we pick up words like BURNED, BLACK SLICK, BODY OUTLINE. Thomas copies the name of the school down, gulps his coffee, and shakes the Sheriff's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Thomas's sedan passing through the vast, empty land.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: And to what do I owe the thrill of a visit from a So Cal homicide cop?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Run of of the mill psycho killer body dismemberment on our end. The usual.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lovely place, Los Angeles.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Got a lead I wanted to run down Chimney Rock way. Thought I'd do the courtesy of telling you first.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Big of you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're welcome to put a babysitter on me if you like.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Son, this is the third biggest county in the country, not even counting the 25,000 square mile Indian reservation right next door, and I've got fewer men than just one of your little palm tree precincts to cover all of it. 'Fraid the only help you're gonna get from me, short of another shoot out at the OK Corral, is that cup of coffee in your hand. A middle-aged secretary enters with a stack of paper.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here's the last week's watch reports.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bobby just called this in from Chimney Rock.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Thomas) Sent a car up there this morning. Teacher complained some vagrant was sleeping in her schoolhouse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to secretary) Damn it, get Bobby on the phone, Clarice. What the hell is this suppose to be?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (re report) May I?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks for the coffee.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as Thomas turns to leave) Small piece of advice, Lt. Dagget, that I give free of charge to all visiting big city policemen: It's wild country up there. Always has been, always will be. You come across anything that snarls, you call me first, hear?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I never turn down advice, Sheriff. Especially when it's free.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A small clump of buildings emerge clinging hopelessly to the earth. The Town.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A former miner's hotel, stone walls and sagging wrought iron.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas tosses his bag onto the bed, opens the balcony door, and looks out on the crumbly shale hills, the abandoned prospecting shacks, and the Chuska Mountains, clouds brewing darkly across its shattered back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : A close-up of the circled newspaper obituary for General Hawthorne. The paper lowers and reveals behind it the general's grave. The dirt around the tomb is loose, recently filled. The grave keeper, a young, gangly, drifter type stands nearby with his shovel.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How long ago was he buried?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Which time?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Somebody dug him up last night. I just finished putting him back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did they take anything?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothin' on the outside.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Thomas's breath escapes in warm clouds here in the unheated, abandoned part of the building. Rats scurry away from feeding on the dark, human-like stain on the floor as Thomas crouches down beside it. He probes the dried, black, crusty flotsam with his ball-point pen. Just like the burned body back at the morgue. Far away you can hear the sounds of children. Of a teacher's voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's only past the final door, into the smallest corner of the building, that the walls become clean and brightly painted by eager third graders. The creepy silence transforms itself into the giggles of children as they bang open the classroom door and whoop themselves outside for recess. The last one out is Katherine. She's surprised to see Thomas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Katherine unlocks a hall cabinet and pulls out a stack of volleyballs. She tosses two to Thomas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Arms full, she pushes the building door open with her shoulder and backs out into the sunshine. She tosses the balls out to the kids.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She sits down beside Thomas on the building's stone steps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The children skitter back and forth playing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas starts away. Pauses.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (suspicious) Can I help you with something?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tom Dagget. I'm with the police.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: About the guy upstairs?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd like to ask you a few questions.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've kinda got my hands full right now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll just tag along.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here, make yourself useful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, everbody stays on the courts today. (kids groan)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What grade is this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All of 'em.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Town doesn't look that small.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nearly all ghosts now. When the copper mine closed it took most of the town with it. We just teach out of this one corner of the schoolhouse now. Rest of it's been abandoned for years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're the only teacher.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yup. Just me. (to kid threatening another)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Randy...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But he -- KATHERINE Do it again and I'll put your head in the door and slam it. (to Thomas) Love and understanding are important tools in education.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Clearly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The man upstairs, did you talk to him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wanted to know what the hell he was doing there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did he say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That it wasn't part of the plan. He looked hurt. Bloody. Like someone had cut him. That happens here. (beat) Was that... stuff... on the floor really him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did any of the children talk to him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (protective) She's home sick from school today.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can I speak with her parents?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're dead. She lives with her grandmother. I'll have to ask her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right. (stands, hands her slip of paper) This is my number at the hotel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you know Arnold Hawthorne?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The General? Saw him here and there. It's a small town.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Military man?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: About a million years ago. His interests lately were more like gardening and herbal tea.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you go to the funeral?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Everyone did. He lived here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No dark hidden secrets?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There are no secrets in small towns, Mr. Dagget, dark or otherwise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Up the crumbly embankment, sitting perched on the roof of an abandoned house, is Gabriel. He watches Thomas walk to his car. He watches the children playing, lifting his nose to snort the air, like a coyote.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas sifts through some clippings on General Hawthrone. Tactical genius. The man who saved Korea. Brutal. Almost court marshalled a dozen times for his inspired savagery. A truly ruthless man -- who spent the last twenty years quietly tending his garden in a dying town.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Small, simple, and woodplanked. The church we saw at the beginning. Thomas sits there, staring at the candles, the altar, the crucifix. He's alone there. But for a creeping buzz. A feeling in the air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas turns in surprise. Gabriel is kneeling in the row behind, inches from his ear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's something cold and creepy about Gabriel. Out of place in here. There's another sound. Teeth chattering far in the back. Thomas turns and sees Jerry, deep in the shadows of the choir box. Jerry waves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Those sunglasses. Impenetrably dark. Like at the skid row flophouse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he walks out, leaving Thomas alone in a place gone suddenly cold.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's unusual to see someone of your age in church on a weekday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't get me wrong. I think it's an excellent sign of character.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Never mind him. He shouldn't even be in here. Least not standing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're not from here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Either are you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm looking for something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you found it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will. Have you found what you're looking for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (appraising him) I don't doubt it. (stands) You'll let me know? When you find it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where are you staying?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm around.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: There's a note waiting for him at the front desk: "Her name is Mary Tsosie. You can talk to her at noon tomorrow. I'll be at the VFW hall tonight -- Katherine."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas sticks his head in through the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's an Indian bingo game. Thomas' eyes drift down the table packed with elderly faces and find Katherine and John the Navaho bus driver. Katherine waves him over. Both her and John are totally obsessed with the game, keeping track of several cards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas lazily glances at his card, his eyes opening suddenly wide.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I got your note.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have a seat. You need a card. Here, play one of mine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, it's okay. Really -- JOHN You must learn to shed your high- strung ways, pale face. You must learn the spirit joy in patience, peace, and making fifty or sixty bucks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: John, this is Mr. Dagget. Says he's with the police, though judging by his coat and basic command of the english language, I don't think it's from anywhere around here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shakes John's hand) Tom. From Los Angeles.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That near Oxnard?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sort of.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Long way from home, Tom-from-Los- Angeles.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, wait. I won. I won!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What? No way -- JOHN Recount! Recount!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Navaho social in full swing -- square dancing. The Indian band on stage plays deeply traditional, inspiring, -- Hank Williams. John easily whirls Katherine around; a steely-eyed, master square dancer. Thomas leans against the wall tugging on a beer. When John releases her for another partner she points at Thomas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She leads him out onto the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She smiles. Gets a smile out of him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Your turn.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, no thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: C'mon, don't be a drip.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not very good at this...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as they dance) No, you're not, are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let me lead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Couples drift off the building's porch and into the street to cool off, smoke, and take a few hits off paper bags. John leans against the brick wall, tugs liberally from his paper bag, and exchanges war hoops with some friends across the street. He passes the bag to Katherine and Thomas.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So how's our star pupil feeling today?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mary? The school doctor came by. Declared it "Non-specific gastrointestinal disorder".
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Latin for "I don't have the slightest fucking idea".
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will she be able to talk with me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's up to her. (to John) Mary's grandmother called a hand trembler.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh oh. Hocus pocus time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that serious?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Depends what the hand trembler says. People call them in when they think a witch or a Yei is trying to sprinkle corpse sickness in their hogan, or if the Night People have been hanging around too much. Night people screw around a lot, but they're good at warning of evil ghosts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who are the Night People?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They come as coyotes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Thomas sits in the truck's bed as they Katherine drives through town. John, on the near side of royally toasted, has his boot stuck out the passenger window. Thomas looks up at the night sky. At its blaze of stars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John drinks again from his bottle, rests his head on the open window and looks out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Beautiful stars out here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Too much fucking sky in the desert. It pushes on you. (sighs) Sometimes I wonder if anyone in heaven even knows this place is here...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Early American bachelor. John collapses onto the couch as Katherine heads for the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She messes with the grounds and filter. Thomas paces the room, looks over the pictures and a few weavings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John closes his eyes and drifts off. Thomas wanders into the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She hands him a mug of coffee.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where do you keep the coffee in this joint?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Above the stove.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What happens if the hand trembler says a ghost has been...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Messing with Mary? If you're smart you say thank you very much and forget about it. But if you're heavy traditional, and Mary's people are serious traditional, you have an Enemy Ghost Way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goddamn expensive. It's a Sing to purify and drive off the corpse sickness. Two days of dancing and ceremony and feeding the whole damn village. Not even to mention hiring the yataallii, if you can even find one these days. And you can bet they don't come cheap. But every clan does it a bit different. Especially Mary's.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Bitter Sky Clan. Hard core reservation. No lights, no running water, no HBO. Their village is out on the edge of Old Woman Butte. Million miles from anything. Witch country. Settled right there in the Dead People Land where no one else would, right on top of the old Anasazi village. They're a dying clan. Just the old ones now. All alone out there in the middle of nothing. (drinks) They can keep it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do people really still believe in it all? Ghosts, Sings, corpse sickness?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Depends, I guess. Sometimes you go along because it's a village thing, or you don't want to disappoint grandma. But sometimes, when you're alone out there, far from town, and the wind kicks up and sneaks into your hogan... I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think John's out for the evening.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Saturday night in Chimney Rock.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So how does a person like you end up teaching here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When I was younger I used to believe that no matter how much you mucked around in your life, one day, if you listened hard enough, a voice would tell you what you were really cut out to do. And when it didn't show up on schedule I decided to go look for it. And I looked in a lot of places, believe me. I drove that road out there so far that the end became the beginning again. And it was when I got here that I realized there never was going to be a voice. So I stopped looking and took the first job they offered me. That make any sense to you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I know all about voices. Problem is not all of them are very nice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How did you end up a cop?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was the evil of two lessers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you always this cryptic?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. When you get to know me I can be down right evasive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Katherine pulls up to drop Thomas off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas climbs out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Thomas lying in his hotel bed, flinching through a dream- filled sleep. There's glimpses of shattered images: War. Death. And a small, dark-haired girl. Thomas's eyes open and fix on the ceiling. Out his window, perched on the railing of his balcony, is something dark and winged. DISSOLVE TO: The honey warmth of dawn heats the bluish, quiet streets of The Town. Across shale hills and abandoned 19th century miner's shacks, there echoes the faint, clear notes of a trumpet. The bluesy notes drift over narrow dead-end streets, junked cars, and the abandoned copper mine out past the end of town.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks for the lift. Tomorrow at noon? At the little girl's house?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: First trailer on the highway past town.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I must say, Mr. Dagget, that you don't seem very like a police officer to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what my bosses keep saying.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I meant it as a compliment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So taken. Goodnight, Miss Henley.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodnight, Tom-from-Los-Angeles.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Deep in the tunneled rock, past the rusting conveyor belts, Gabriel sits in a small cave blowing Miles Davis on his trumpet. There's just the blanket he sits on and a single candle. Jerry comes around the corner.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Get any sleep? (Jerry only stares)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just kidding.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Katherine climbs out of her pick-up she sees several of her students standing in a circle. Crouched in the center, talking to them, is a man. Gabriel. Jerry stands nearby. Gabriel is showing a boy his trumpet. Demonstrating where to put his fingers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The boy puffs lightly. The trumpet emits a piercing, clear note that SHATTERS a window high up in the abandoned part of the building. The youngsters whoop and applaud.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Timmy opens his mouth we clearly see Gabriel looking down into it. Looking for something...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Katherine approaches the scene warily. The children all beg for their turn. Gabriel selects Sandra, one of Mary's second grade friends, and puts her on his knee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She can barely get her fingers around the trumpet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gently pushes down her chin with his thumb, opens her mouth, and gazes in. Katherine enters the circle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabriel looks up, unperturbed, and smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The kids reluctantly shuffle off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He has the same sunglasses as Simon. The same cold, creepy air about him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jerry suddenly snorts loudly, trying to retrieve a sticky red glop that starts running out of his nose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He climbs to his feet and stands close to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stands there a beat. That terrible coldness that swirls about him. The shriek of ghosts under his breath. Then he climbs into the rambler with Jerry and pulls away. Katherine watches the car drive off, then yells over to the school janitor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Katherine gets into her pickup and starts the engine.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...There, and there. Now pucker your lips... aim it that way, and just blow a little bit, this is a special trumpet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Very good, Timmy. Very good. Here, have a Junior Mint on me. Open up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who's next?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And who are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sandra.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And did you see the man upstairs, Sandra?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A little.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you talk to him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And who did, Sandra. Who talked to the man?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mary.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And where is Mary, Sandra?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She isn't here. She's sick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've got very pretty teeth, Sandra. Here, let me see...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell do you think you're doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just talking to the kids, Ma'am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get off his knee, Sandra. Everyone else, go inside. Now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Bye, Gabriel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: See ya, kids. Be sure to study your math.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a long story.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ignore him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Everyone else does.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know what the hell is going on, but you both better get out of here. Right now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're right...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...You have no idea what's going on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Al! Keep an eye on the children for me. I'll be right back. And call the sheriff.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sheriff? What the hell do I tell him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just call.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Katherine drives through the main drag and out past the fringe of town. As she passes the old copper mine she sees, parked near the mine's tunnel entrance, Gabriel's rambler.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Katherine pulls up, she's surprised to see Thomas climbing out of his own car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : On the sandy lot that extends back from the trailer is a wizened cottonwood tree. Katherine, Thomas, and Mary are seated beneath its shade. Katherine is protective of the little girl, running a hand maternally through her hair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a dreamy, far-away look in Mary's eyes. It worries Katherine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary lowers her head and shuts her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas and Katherine exchange looks. Mary's pretty eyes rise again as she calmly asks, in that cute little eight year old voice:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas looks to Katherine for an explanation, but she's as confused as him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary's been explaining this in a girlish, show-'n-tell kind of way. Suddenly her face cracks as her voice chokes with a sob.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She buries herself into Katherine's arms, sobbing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary suddenly pushes away and runs back toward the trailer, into the arms of her grandmother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The grandmother turns and walks back to the trailer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Katherine turns from trailer and looks at him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You weren't suppose to be here till noon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a little early yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wanted to check on her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That makes two of us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How are you feeling, pumpkin?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Better.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is Mr. Dagget, Mary. He'd like to ask you some questions. You don't have to answer if you don't want to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mary, when you talked to man up in the building -- MARY -- Simon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, Simon. What did Simon say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiles) That's funny. "Simon says".
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right. Like the game.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm good at it. I'm very clever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll have to play together sometime.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Simon even said so. He also asked if I could keep a secret.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what was that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Something he gave me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What, pumpkin?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then it wouldn't be a secret.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a good friend not to tell, Mary. But I'm a friend of Simon's too. So if you ever want to tell, you can to me. Okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a secret...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...But sometimes it hurts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you ever killed a chinaman?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No Mary, I haven't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They don't bleed. Not the way you and I do. Or maybe it was just the cold...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've killed them, you know. Lots. You could always tell when they were coming. There'd be the trumpets first. Every note flat. Then those songs... After that they'd charge. Right down through the snow. The guns would freeze and it would be just knives... It was so cold and there were so many of them. But I was smarter than they were. Even at Chosin, I was smarter...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It scares me, Miss Henley. I hate it. Please, make it stop!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Make it stop!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rocking her) It's okay... It's okay...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, I didn't mean to -- GRANDMOTHER It's all right, Miss Henley. We know you love Mary...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are we going to do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's going to have the Enemy Ghost Way. We leave this afternoon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where will they do the ceremony?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In the home village. The Hand Trembler must have found corpse sickness...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're taking her away? Shouldn't she see a doctor?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's already seen a doctor. (then, under her breath) That son of a bitch...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gabriel the children called him. The little shit was hanging around my kids this morning asking about Mary. He and his buddy make a real pair.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe it's time I checked out Mr. Gabriel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know where he parks his car.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Katherine and Thomas drive back down the road leading to town.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pulls over to the side near the copper mine entrance. No sign of the rambler.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas drives up the dirt path to the mine's tunnel entrance. They climb out and stand near its mouth. In the dust is the rambler's tracks and several footprints leading into the mine. Thomas steps up to the edge of the tunnel. It's a black, yawning thing that swallows the sunlight whole for breakfast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pops his trunk and takes out a flashlight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas switches on the light and takes a tentative step inside.
direction.name: direction
