dialogue.raw_text: Chinamen? Chosin? I've never heard her talk like that before.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Chosin Reservoir was a Korean war battle the Marines had against the Chinese, supposedly the bloodiest hand-to-hand fighting of the century. Someone been teaching that to your class?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, right next to Jack 'N Jill.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where would she have heard it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nobody I can think of. (beat) Maybe one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: General Hawthorne.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did she know him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He didn't like children.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You couldn't and tell a story like that to one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was there earlier.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If I was smart I'd call the Sheriff or somebody in town who knows this place. Then again, there is one thing worse than getting killed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Looking like an idiot if it's nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll come along.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, if someone has to fall a hundred feet down a black pit, he should at least be on official duty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then again, it is kind of spooky in there. Here, you can hold the flashlight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The sun very quickly becomes a memory. And after the first bend it isn't even that anymore. There's only the glow of the flashlight; glancing off the abrupt edges of tunneled rock. Here and there are the flotsam of a bankrupt industry; dented ore carts lying on their side, rusted drill bits, piles of support timbers. And all around them the sucking blackness of the earth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They walk further down into the mine. The atmosphere becomes close and creepy. Thomas has been following tracks left in the dusty floor that abruptly disappear. He stops and sighs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's cold...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: suddenly SHRIEKS out of the darkness, glancing off Thomas's shoulder and TANGLING in Katherine's hair. She screams and spins around, loosing her footing and half falling into a yawning ore chute she hadn't seen beside her. Thomas rushes over and pulls her out. She climbs shakily to her feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas takes a last pass at the mine shaft with his flashlight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he turns to leave the flashlight burns out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He bangs it once against his thigh before he notices for the first time a dim, amber light coming from a space between the rocks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But his gun's out at his side. Just in case. They follow the light to the gap in the rock, gingerly stepping into
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah... Sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I've seen enough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wonderful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. Maybe a bum or something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: That could easily belong to a bum. It's Gabriel and Jerry's digs. Just the moldy blanket, single oil lamp, piles of twinkie wrappers, And something else. From outside the cave it's the same whine, the same blurryness that drips off Gabriel like sweat. But once they step into the room, into the lair, it suddenly jumps in volume. This is where Gabriel sleeps, and it's thicker here, like honey on the walls. Thomas has difficulty focusing his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Thomas can't hear Katherine anymore, her voice has disappeared beneath the whine. As it becomes too much he leans his weight against the rock wall and shuts his eyes. It's then they come. Flashes of images: Of screams and fire. Of impossible vistas of emptiness and death. And shrieking overhead, shrieking everywhere; grotesque, winged creatures with no eyes. Some with faces we know; Gabriel, Simon, and the gargoyle. All these images are being jammed into both their minds by the cave. Thomas forces his eyes open but the scenes playing all around him won't go away. Tears are running down Katherine's face as she stands there locked in the same images. Thomas stumbles about the room as if drunk, the visions, incomprehendibly black visions of war and destruction on an alien plateau, eat his brain. He sinks to his knees and begins to cry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Katherine's curled up on the floor like a child, weeping. The images are driving them mad. Thomas, fighting the insanity pounding at him, crawls pathetically across the floor to the oil lamp. His fingers grasp it spasmotically as he rises to his knees and leans back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He HEAVES the lamp against the cave wall, where it EXPLODES, the oil erupting into a swirling blaze that CONSUMES the corner. The images break a second in the heat and light and sucking wind. Just long enough for Thomas to grab Katherine's arm and pull her out of the room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Do you feel it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh no... Oh God no...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Katherine and Thomas lie in the dust outside the mine's tunnel entrance. Catching their breath. Trying to organize and repair the short circuits in their brains. Thomas rolls on his side, squints at the sun. Katherine's voice is faint and raspy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He squeezes a handful of dirt in his hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The tears start rolling down her face. She looks up and shouts at the endless sky above them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He laughs hopelessly at the insanity of it all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Katherine climbs abruptly to her feet and walks for the car.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What... What was that? Hell?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...No. The voices. They were screaming and fighting over... theology. They don't sweat much about that in hell. But they do in... heaven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The son of a bitch. He carries it around with him like a photo album. A big, greasy cloud wherever he goes. They all do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How can that be heaven? Jesus Christ. How? I don't even believe in heaven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You dumb fucking assholes! How could you have done that!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That extra chapter by St. John was right. It's a war... Just like the first one. Just like when the angel Michael beat Lucifer and cast him out. Only now they've turned on each other... Turned on each other in a civil war over theology.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh sweet God, theology. (sighs) "God's wild bunch". (shouts) God's morons!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do you know know so much about that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I just know. (shakes his head) Yes folks, the good news is that there's life after death in heaven. The bad news is that it's as screwed up as here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They were like us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They are us. Aborted children. And they need us. They need our corrupt, dark souls for their fight. They need...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Mary.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know what this is. I don't know what I believe. I don't know if my sanity is lying back in that cave flopping around waiting for me. But I know one thing. Those... Those things aren't taking her!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Katherine and Thomas drive along in silence. Finally,
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: In those... visions... did you ever see... God?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Me either.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Katherine and Thomas open the trailer door and enter cautiously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas looks out the window and notices for the first time, parked behind the trailer, Gabriel's rambler. He immediately pulls out his pistol, runs for the closed door at the end of the hall and KICKS it in. The door FLIES open, revealing Gabriel sitting on the bed beside Mary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His gun's leveled at Gabriel's head. The angel sits there impassively, then smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jerry suddenly LEAPS out from behind the door and TACKLES Thomas to the carpet. The gun skitters to one side as Jerry SINKS his rotting teeth into Thomas's shoulder. Thomas cries out and SLAMS his fist against Jerry's head, knocking off an ear. Gabriel turns back to Mary's frightened face and smiles as he runs a hand through her hair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Katherine suddenly HAMMERS Gabriel across the side of the head with a chair, KNOCKING him to the floor. As he gets up she HITS him again. Thomas manages to bring his leg up and KICKS Jerry hard against the chest, forcing him off. Gabriel GRABS both of Katherine's legs and PULLS, CRASHING her flat on her back. Thomas scrambles for his gun, grabs it, and as Jerry comes at him again spins and FIRES twice. The slugs RIP into Jerry's chest and knock him to his knees. As the putrid, curdled juices pump lumpily out of him, Jerry looks up at Thomas and smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas FIRES a slug into his forehead. Jerry's brain winks out as he collapses to the floor, dead. Thomas's gun is abruptly WRENCHED from his hand onto the bed as Gabriel NAILS him with a thrown lamp, vaults the bed between them, and grabs him by the collar, SLAMMING Thomas up against the wall. He looks down at Jerry's finally lifeless corpse, incensed at Thomas's handiwork.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He THROWS Thomas down onto a table, SPLINTERING it. Katherine climbs shakily to her knees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabriel walks over to the bed. The moment he gets close, Mary lifts Thomas's pistol up from the sheets and SHOOTS him twice, the impact KNOCKING him on his ass. Katherine rushes to Mary, scoops her up and runs for the door. She pauses beside Thomas, still lying in the wreckage of the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Katherine disappears through the bedroom doorway. Gabriel spins around and stands. Thomas leaps from a ragged crouch, HITTING Gabriel low with a body-block. It's like butting concrete. Gabriel picks up Thomas by the scruff of the neck and HEAVES him THROUGH the flimsy room paneling. Thomas CRASHES with a mass of splinters into the kitchen. He stumbles backward hopelessly as Gabriel peruses him through the trailer. He desperately throws pots, glasses, anything at Gabriel. Finally trapped, he scrambles up onto the dinner table, SCATTERING salt and sugar bowls, and DIVES through the levored window.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mary?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get away from her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know. Son of a bitch, the priest wanna-be actually figured it out. That's a rare club, son. At least down here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Back away from the kid, man. Now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She won't feel anything, honest. I'll have to tear her apart of course -- just the way it goes -- but it'll be all right in the end. A good catholic boy like you, Mr. Daggett, you should be on my side.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goddamn it -- GABRIEL You're gonna have to watch that profanity.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It'll only be a moment...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks man, I appreciate it. You're a sport.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You little pest, do you have any idea how hard it is to get one of those?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You son of a bitch, why? Why do this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because I'm an angel, you miserable wretch! I kill first borns while their mothers watch! I turn whole cities into salt! I even, when I feel like it, rip the souls from little girls! And from now until eternity, the only thing you'll be able to count on in your pathetic little existence is never knowing why! (deep breath) I'm wasting my time here. (turns to Mary) C'mon petunia, let's get on with it...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go. Go!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Thomas, in a hail of shattered glass, smacks the red earth, pulls himself up to his knees and tries to stumble and crawl away as Gabriel BANGS open the trailer door and stomps down the stairs toward Katherine, her arms around Mary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He eases his gait, measuring the distance to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's just those sunglasses coming. Those endless pits of black.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Katherine lifts Thomas's pistol and FIRES. Again. Again. The slugs BANG off the corregated metal, SMASH a window, KICK up some dust, And PUNCTURE the propane tank beneath the trailer.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...Have Her!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ! The entire trailer EXPLODES in a fiery cloud of TWISTING METAL. Katherine huddles Mary close to the ground as flaming chunks WHACK everywhere. Gabriel is HAMMERED to the earth and disappears in the rolling fire cloud. Thomas, further away, is KNOCKED head-over-heels in the ruddy dust. The fire cloud dissipates quickly into the sky, leaving behind scorched brush, and little else, crackling softly. Gabriel's body looks blackened and still. Katherine rushes to Thomas, who's pulled himself up to his knees, a ragged slice above his eye bleeding badly. She helps him to his feet and over to the pickup, where he sits down against the tire as Katherine pulls out her first aid kit. Mary's there, standing with her shaken grandmother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary's knelt down beside Thomas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A sheriff car ROARS up, the two deputies exiting warily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Katherine's wiping the blood out of Thomas's eye. Gasping from the shearing pain, he tosses an ID at the foot of the deputy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From somewhere back in town there's the growl of a volunteer fire engine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The pain's unbareable. Katherine dabs his cut with disinfectant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Again, the pain. The second deputy has walked over to Gabriel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The volunteer fire engine growls up through the weeds, drowning out Thomas's words. Two firemen kneel down beside him with medical kits. The deputy has walked over to his partner and the two are dragging back between them a cuffed, comatose Gabriel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas tries to get up, but the pain and a hand from the firemen keep him down. As the deputies pass, he manages to desperately grab the one's pant cuff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabriel's head lies low between the shoulders. The deputy looks with concern at the firemen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The deputy nods. As they carry on to the car with Gabriel, the angel turns his head slightly and smiles a smile only for Thomas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The patrol car pulls away. As the firemen walk back to their engine, Thomas looks frantically at Katherine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They lock eyes. Then Katherine without a word helps Thomas up into the passenger side of the pickup. Mary gathers her grandmother into the pickup's bed and climbs up beside her as Katherine starts the engine. The firemen turn in confusion as the truck peels out of the lot and up onto the road.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (re grandmother) Where...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She was coming up the street.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is Gabriel dead?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're not like you and me. You've got to cut their hearts out. The only thing God gave them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell happened here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looks at it, hands it to partner) That's a start. How about the rest of it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That man over there. He's wanted. Murder. I'm taking him in. (grimaces)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shit...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think you're going to the hospital first.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I have to --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is he alive?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #2 He's alive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cuff him. We'll take him to the hospital in our car.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, you don't understand. You have to let me have him --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hoarse, faint) You'll never hold him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take off his sunglasses... Jesus Christ, just take off his sunglasses...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (re Thomas) He'll be all right. Just a bad hit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to partner) Let's get a splint.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We have to get out of here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But your head...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you want Mary to stay alive past sundown we have to leave, and we have to do it now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Katherine's truck shoots by. Just before town, near the copper mine, it slows down at a junction. And there, lying on its side down the embankment, is the sheriff's patrol car. A single, bent tire turns aimlessly. Katherine hits the gas and takes the junction that leads away from town, out onto the endless expanse of the plateau.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bandage on Thomas's forehead covers most of one eye. He closes the other tightly, riding a spasm of pain, before letting his forehead rest against the door glass and gazing out at the empty tracks of land.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Katherine looks over her shoulder to Mary's grandmother sitting in the truck bed. She nods in understanding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Katherine's pickup passing alone through the wrinkled desert.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where are we going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mary's village.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A trading post with a few pumps, growing orange in the weakening afternoon light. A scruffy dog barks constantly as the teenage Indian sticks the nozzle in Katherine's pickup. Still glassy-eyed with throbbing pain, Thomas takes another handful of aspirin and climbs out of the cab. There's a tiny, weatherbeaten church across the weedy lot from the trading post with a pay phone bolted to it. Thomas crunches across the lot, picks up the receiver, and punches in some numbers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And Thomas hangs up. He backs away from the phone and for the first time notices the church it's attached to.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: County Coroner's office, Assistant Coroner Raphael speaking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Willie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tom?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You weren't crazy, man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Thomas steps inside. It's empty and there's some doubt whether it's been used in a generation. The pews are dusty and scraped, some broken down completely. Thomas sits in one and looks across the space and dust and years to the crucifix hanging behind the altar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The pew creaks and groans as he shifts his weight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus' pressed-metal eyes gaze only upward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas holds his face in his hands a silent moment. When it raises we see the raw hurt in the eyes as he shouts,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The only reply is dust dancing in the light and the rumble of semis on the highway. Standing in the back, watching Thomas with tears welling in her eyes, is Katherine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : The road's turned to dirt and the plateau into a maze of ragged cliffs and brutally hacked canyons. The light is shadowy and golden now as Katherine's pickup turns off the small dirt road onto an even smaller one that winds impossibly up the side of a volcanic butte. Higher and higher the truck climbs on the rutted and treacherous path, till at last it crests the ridge and comes upon
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So what's the deal, huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean, do you have any kind of plan here? Cause I'm just about of ideas, friend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you even listen? Do you still come to places like this? Old Man, you have been calling me most of my goddamn life, but every time I get close, you just keep moving that far away. What's it to be? You want me to kill your henchmen? Can't you even control your own killers anymore?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you want from me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Perched frighteningly on the leading edge of Old Woman Butte, this is the home of the Bitter Sky Clan. The village is a small grouping of ancient adobe walled hogans first built a thousand years ago by the Anasazi. There's no electricity here, no TV antennas or frozen yogurt. Just the slow curl of cooking fires drifting up through smoke holes and the stern, deeply lined face of an old Navaho man approaching the pickup as Katherine stops. The old man wears jeans, a bright maroon silk shirt, and a black felt reservation hat with a turkey feather. He holds in his right hand a small leather case.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The old man, Bartholomew Grey Horse, walks up to Mary and her grandmother sitting in the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Several villagers approach and greet Mary and her grandmother, some nodding politely to Thomas and Katherine as they climb out of the cab. Nearly all of them are elderly. Thomas, one eye still half-shut by a bandage, walks over to the village's edge where a short stone wall, and little else, separates the adobe homes from the long, 2000 foot drop to the desert floor. He leans against it and gazes out on a view that must encompass half the world. In all directions, for tens upon tens of miles, there are only volcanic spires and crumbling buttes, all reduced from up here to short, ominous playthings. A village truly alone in the world.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's appeared beside him. Thomas crouches down to her level and smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary's sight is on the view, eyeing it critically.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas's voice sighs sadly as he runs a hand softly through her hair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary's eyes fill with tears as her grandmother appears and leads her back to the adobe hogans. Grey Horse, the yataalii, is there now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Night creeps over the Chuska Mountains across the crusty caliche flats and over the village, pushing back the dying day to a thin, fading blue line etched across the horizon. As the darkness settles on the hogans we see a glimmer of light from within and the rising, guttural chants of the yataalii.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I am Bartholomew Grey Horse, born to the Deer Spring Clan, born for the Slow Talking People. Today I am the yataalii for Mary Tsosie of the Bitter Sky Clan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ya-tah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ya-tah-hey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is a good place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Separate water source. Stocked grain. Only one possible approach. A man could, with the proper defenses, hold off an entire battalion for weeks. Months.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Which one of you is that talking, Mary? Or do you even know anymore?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We will start the Sing soon to remove the Yei spirit and stop the ghost sickness.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This might not be the work of a Navaho ghost.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's all the same.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Under the village, beneath the surface of the butte, is the large communal kiva room. Accessible by a single ladder through a single smoke hole, it is down here that the village performs its Enemy Ghost Way for Mary. The little girl is there, attended by her grandmother, sitting stoically still on a blanket as Grey Horse, grasping his painted prayer sticks, by the glow of a fire chants the Enemy Ghost Way cure. Katherine's eyes sting in the smokey air as she watches Grey Horse take from his case small handfulls of colored sand that he pours in fine patterns onto the floor. The whole Bitter Sky Clan surrounds them. Old, lined faces. A small, dying people here to support its last granddaughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Katherine stands there in the chilly darkness outside the kiva. Mary's grandmother, passing with some other women, pauses and squeezes Katherine's arm.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Now we sleep, Katherine. Tomorrow, after dark, we begin again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The fire has died to embers, casting its weak glow on a now empty room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Katherine wanders along the edge of the village, turning up her collar under a blinding mass of stars. There's nothing beyond the village. Not a light, not a sound. Say the wind. It is the icy brush of wind on her body that now whispers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like the wind, it is low and thin and hoarse. Like the wind it seems to come from everywhere. And, like the wind, it is utterly without pity or remorse. Katherine turns. Perched on the wall behind her in a low crouch is a figure clad entirely in layers of black. Its head and hands are hairless and waxy white. There are eyes in this winged head, but blood chilling ones of putrid yellow. There are endless scars and shapes and wrinkles, but mostly, only, there are the eyes. Katherine gulps down, with only partial success, the hysteria rising in her throat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's takes all her strength to look upon him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The eyes narrow. Rippling pools of unfathomable evil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a crouched silhouette beside the figure. Dimmer. Skinny. A wheezing sycophant. An afterthought. Katherine backs away from both of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Katherine stops. Faces him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sycophant shivers and ruffles something feathery under its cloak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The figure cranes his neck around to the horizon beyond them. The movement makes a liquid, snapping sound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns back to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The figure shifts his perch on the wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The figure's face darkens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The figure straightens up, stretching its spine.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Katherine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh Lord, I can't do this. I can't do this anymore...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We must talk, Katherine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're... You're... (tries to form the word) ...God?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: God is love, Katherine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't love you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't. I can't do this tonight. Go away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can kill you, Katherine. I can lay you out and fill your mouth with your mother's feces. Or I can talk with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am here, before you, in a form to put you at ease.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I rarely do this in person. I am, perhaps, somewhat out of touch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you one of them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're not an angel?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I am an angel. A very special one. The first. The oldest. The naive eagle scout, he once loved me above all others, and I him. It was the only true love for either of us, but like all true love, it couldn't possibly last.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The winged party boys will come, Katherine. They'll come to feed on the guts of your little Mary.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you care?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have my interests...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The naive eagle scout, he has his interests too. He even has a place for them, as I do for mine. Big, shiny place. You'd like it. Only it's been empty for a long time. Can't open till after the resurrection. The problem's with the hired help. Always had problems with the hired help. They're arrogant, boastful little pricks. Not like me. What I did I did for love. But they, the winged party boys, even before the park could open for its first customer, they started fighting over the popcorn stand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You see, Katherine, heaven can't start accepting guests till this fight is settled. And without people, there is no heaven. All those good and true souls left mouldering in the ground clutching their H-tickets and waiting and waiting and waiting... Some, lying down there with the worms century after century, they start to get doubts about the whole program. That's when, out of sheer boredom, some of them come to me. Because I'm always open for business. 24 hours a day, seven days a week. Even on Christmas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Some of the angels cheat. They sneak a few souls in to help with the fight. The really dark ones. And now one of them has found a special soul so wonderfully sick that it might just win it for them. And if one side wins, even the wrong one, then there's no fight. And if there's no fight, there can be a heaven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And if there's a heaven?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd be very unhappy. (beat) I am here to help you and the little bitch not because I love you, not because I care about you, but because I want this war to go on and on and on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I bring you the chance to save your Mary, Katherine. And along the way, stop the resurrection.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen when I speak. Now go to bed, Katherine. Tomorrow, I promise you, is a big day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Thomas's sitting on the hard-packed floor, leaning against the adobe wall, maybe trying to sleep. Mostly trying to ignore the thumping pain in his head. The oil lamp's flame shudders in the gust of Katherine opening the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She sits down on the floor beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She carefully unwraps the blood-soaked gauze.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She peels back the compress and dabs the wound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas suddenly slams his fist against the wall in anger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The ache in his head's flared up. He leans it back against the wall to ease the pain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Katherine finishes taping the new bandage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A wind outside rustles through the hogans.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pauses, the old emotions creeping back up on him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He blinks back the tears welling in his eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The oil lamp wanes and fades. Katherine lays her head on Thomas's shoulder, and as darkness swallows them he holds her. They hold each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : John the bus driver lying fully dressed on his bed asleep. The night breeze through the window, and maybe something else, tickles his nose. His eyes open, blink, turn left, right, then up,
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Is it over?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For now. They start again tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And at the end of it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Enemy Way chant removes the invading yei ghost.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will it work on a general's soul?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll see. (beat) How's the head?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Still attached. Barely.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here, I'll change the bandage.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Does that hurt?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then I must be doing it wrong.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I saw the devil tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How nice. Which one?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The main one. Satan. Lucifer. The dark angel. You know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did he have to say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That he did it all for love. That and I have a choice. Mary's life or a billion souls waiting in the pipeline for heavenland to open.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're not kidding, are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Satan? You're sure?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You had to be there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why wasn't I!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We can double date next time if it's that important to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't understand, I've spent my whole life... (looks upward) I don't suppose it would occur to anyone in authority to fill me in on what's going on every once in awhile, huh? Shit!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did he say anything about the Nicene Council? About the rank of Jesus Christ in the holy Trinity?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It didn't seem important to him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you a priest?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A near miss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a long story.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This may be your last chance to tell it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The other night, you were talking about waiting for a voice to call you to something. Well, let me tell you, the worst thing that can happen to you is to be called to something. Since I can remember a voice from somewhere deep in the Church called me. So loud and so often that by thirteen I knew I was going to be a priest. You know what that's like? My parents, friends, all of them thought I was crazy. But see, I had this voice. The voice that kept coaxing me along, telling me there was a reason. So I entered the seminary and was half way to my starched white collar when my mother, father, and my little brother were wiped out in a car crash.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I had never asked anything of the voice. Not when the neighborhood kids made fun of me, not when my father looked down at me like some knock-kneed faggot. I never questioned a damn thing. But on the morning I spent looking down at three parallel graves, I asked it one question. Why. Why were these people taken from me? And the voice, that same voice that would wrench me out of my sleep some nights with its jabbering, it was suddenly stone silent. It was the only question I ever asked of it and it just left me hanging in the fucking wind...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So after that I traded in priest school for homicide school. Because if God wouldn't talk to me the devil sure as hell would, and his ways were a lot easier to understand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We've never seen God, have we? Not in any of this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, He's certainly a shy son of a bitch, I'll give Him that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe we're not supposed to. Maybe that's faith.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you still have faith in anything, Katherine?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have faith in Mary. And that I'm going to save that little girl from those creeping things out there. From all of them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe you were called to something after all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe we both were.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: And see Gabriel perched on the headboard, staring down at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: John's eyes open wide in shock. Gabriel's skin is blackened and blistered in parts. Whole shards of his shirt are missing. John tries to sit up but Gabriel forces his head back down with his palm. With the ease of a spider he slides down and beside John.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabriel leans said nose in very close and whispers,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabriel extends a blistered, open palm over John's face.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Heavy sleeper, John.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't -- Don't hurt me, man. My wallet's in the dresser.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be such a materialist, John. (sees empty bourbon bottle on dresser, sighs) No end to your bad habits.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A moment of your time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You ought to have that nose looked at, man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where are they, John? Katherine and Mary? Where would they go?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What? Mary? I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure you do. Think hard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, really. I don't know. The school maybe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now you're not even trying, John. You're Katherine's best friend. She tells you everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm just the driver, y'know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can help you remember, John...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We see Gabriel leaning over John as a sickly yellow glow begins to rise and reflect off the walls. Beneath it comes John's worst and deepest screams...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Gabriel SPLASHING the soot off his face and arms in a small, institutional bathroom. He looks at himself in the mirror, runs a hand through his hair, and walks out the door into
direction.name: direction

result.heading: FROM THE OTHER SIDE OF THE ROOM

direction.raw_text: At the end of it is the intensive care unit, that institutional purgatory where a small handful of patients, wired and tubed and oxygenated, lay inconclusively between life and death. There's a nurse's station there, all health status video screens and a single nurse that looks up from her work at Gabriel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The nurse reaches for the telephone. Gabriel takes it away from her with one hand and with the other grasps her face open-palmed and whispers,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The nurse slides out of her chair and collapses to the floor. Gabriel pulls out the metal clipboards holding each patient's chart and flips through them, tossing one after another aside as unsuitable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Satisfied, he steps over to one of the beds, pulls back the curtain and sits down beside an unconscious, middle-aged woman. He watches patiently, listening the beeping scrawl of the EKG above her. It was weak to begin with but now it's faltering badly, becoming the unsynched etchings of a child. A beeping alarm has begun to ring and her breathing is slowing to nothing. At the last possible moment Gabriel places his fingers across her face, whispering to her, coaxing her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The EKG's still flat but the woman is breathing. She begins to choke, to cough, then suddenly sits up and opens her eyes. She looks in disbelief around her, finally settling on Gabriel's grin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A look of utter desolation and sadness sweeps over her as she begins to cry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : The sun cresting the Lukachukais and warming with honey colored reflection the interior of the hogan. Katherine's head is still on Thomas's shoulder, the two of them asleep sitting against the wall. Katherine opens her eyes and rises stiffly. She looks out the simple window to the glow of morning without expression, turns, and walks out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Can I help you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Someone's going to die here soon. I'll just be a minute.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's no visitors allowed in ICU.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The timing's important. I can smell these things, you know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go to sleep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Recovering... Recovering... Stable... (finally settles on one) Deteriorating critical.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whoa, not just yet. Come on back. That's it...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, no...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, c'mon, don't start... (looks at chart)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rachael. Here... (hands her kleenex) It's only for a short time. (grins) Promise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mary's Grandmother and some of the other elderly villagers are attending Mary as Katherine enters. Mary is sitting up in her bed. She smiles at Katherine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grey Horse is kneeling near the bed preparing a bowl drink. Into it he crushes charcoal, dodge weed, juniper and ghost plant. This he stirs, heats over flame, and feeds to Mary. She grimaces and leans back in the bed as Grey Horse says a brief prayer.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hi, Miss Henley.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi, pumpkin. Good morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Katherine runs into Thomas outside the hogan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She accepts a mug, blowing a cloud of steam off the top.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas looks up. She's referring to Lucifer, who's appeared perched on the edge of the low, eye-level hogan roof. The sycophant is also nearby, chattering its teeth and staring at Katherine with jealous, rabid eyes. Lucifer shivers, a claw turning up the collar of his cloak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The swimming, bottomless eyes fall on Thomas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas can't bring himself to say anything. To form the words.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas gingerly hands him the cup. The angel Lucifer lifts it, and with something unimaginably awful darting out of his mouth, drinks. He offers the mug back to Thomas for a sip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He finishes it. Cranes his neck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you know instantly, in the bottom of your stomach, that those eyes mean it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas hesitates, holds the gaze, then turns and leaves. In an instant Lucifer sweeps down from the hogan roof to Katherine's side. Face and eyes and maggot breath uncomfortably close, he smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lucifer places a cloaked arm around her shoulder and leads her to the walled edge to look out across the endless plateau. His mouth presses against her ear and whispers,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : A tiny speck on the empty horizon. It grows, takes shape, and finally becomes a red convertible rambler as it WOOSHES past on a desolate throat of forgotten highway. Gabriel's at the wheel. Beside him, grey-blonde hair streaming out behind her, is Rachael, recently lifted from the file- and-forget section of the hospital ICU. She tilts her head up. Lets the sun warm her pallor. Just a sociopathic angel and his somewhat deceased babe out for a top-down cruise across a sixty million year old desert. It could happen.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How's the head?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shitty. Coffee?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are we going to do if he comes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean when, right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When he comes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's no phone here? Radio? (she just looks at him) Stupid question. (beat) If we were smart we'd leave. Get to a town. A sheriff station.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mary's ceremony isn't over yet. The Enemy Ghost Way. The alien spirit hasn't been driven out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you really believe in the ceremony?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would you have believed in any of this three days ago?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nods) So we stay and dump the General's soul.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have the gun?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: With one shot left. The spares -- (sniffs his shirt)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And a change of clothing, are all still at the hotel. (sighs) We're going to have to come up with something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We could always ask him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I always forget how cold it gets in the desert.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Daggett, I presume. How's the faith?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come come, must you be so wishy-washy about everything? With the absent- minded eagle scout, I can see that. But you're looking at the devil man, say something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fuck you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Much better. Can I have some coffee?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Keep it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have come to remind you that the winged party boys are just that: spoiled boys. You are armed, however pathetically, with the one thing they never really understood: theology. It's not much, but that's life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is this supposed to be our "win one for The Ripper" speech?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't press your luck, Mr. Daggett.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go and get ready, Thomas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you ever considered Katherine, that the great absentee landlord, the soft-eyed eagle scout your childhood prayers are for, is just using you? That you're only the exterminator to get rid of his pests?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: God's junkies are coming, Katherine. And when they do, all hell is going to break loose...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A reality bruised waitress, Madge, sets down a coffee and milkshake before Gabriel. He downs the shake in one belt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The waitress' eyes move from the guy with sunglasses and burn marks on his shirt to the woman sitting alone outside in the rambler.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Madge has a lot of things she misses in her life, but one of them she decides isn't Gabriel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabriel downs the coffee, stands, and tosses a bill on the counter.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Say, Ma'am, any idea where I can find Old Woman Butte?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's on the reservation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't suppose you could be just a tad more specific. Madge.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Isn't your friend hungry?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not for a while, I'm afraid. Funniest thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take 522 to the Sonsela Wash cut- off. First dirt road go left. Twenty, twenty-five miles you'll see it. Big, black and all alone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I doubt we'll meet again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Suits me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Thomas drags a heavy chain from Katherine's truck and begins fastening it to a post. Lucifer watches perched on a nearby rooftop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lucifer just smiles or sneers or whatever he does with that hideous mouth.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You could always lend a hand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Grey Horse begins laying out his prayer instruments as Mary is prepared with paint and oils.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Katherine leans against the doorway, nervously watching the horizon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : The sky thinning into uneasy pastels as the sun falls unceremoniously toward the mountains. A few lanterns have been lit, and from inside the kiva can be heard the chants of the Navaho Enemy Ghost Way. Katherine's eyes are still on a horizon dropping off into shadow. She stiffens. There, at the end of the earth, appears a silent plume of dust. It could be anybody's car, but it can only be one car. Thomas steps up beside her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas sticks his head into the kiva, speaks softly to one of the elderly villagers attending the ceremony.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A fire has been built on the kiva's floor. Through the choking smoke can be seen Mary lying on a mat as Grey Horse chants to the yei spirits and adds fine colored earth to the growing sand painting beside her. His voice rises and falls in guttural syntax. He's coaxing. Coaxing the alien spirit out of the child.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pulls his head out and hands Katherine the pistol.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a pause and for a moment their eyes lock. She touches his arm, almost says something, then disappears into the kiva. Thomas closes the door behind her. He turns and looks out at the distant plume of dust. Growing closer.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He's coming.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is there any way to speed this up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lock the door.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stay inside. It's only one round, so make it count.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Radio turned up, sophomoric grin glued on his face, Gabriel roars past and begins the snaking climb up the side of the butte. The sun has almost completely slipped away now, leaving the land a deathly bluish grey. The road flattens out at the top of the butte and Gabriel can see the village glowing at the far end. He punches the rambler, winding it up for the last stretch, and pats the blonde on the knee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe not. There's a sudden glint of metal in the headlights as Thomas at the last moment PULLS UP the heavy chain and HOOKS it over the far post. Gabriel does something pointless with the brakes and SLAMS forward into it. The whole rear of the car STANDS UP on impact, PITCHING Gabriel through the windshield into the dust. Thomas steps out from behind the post armed with an iron bar. The rambler hisses and belches a death rattle as he cautiously walks toward the spot of gloom where Gabriel lies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas's feet crunch softly closer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas doesn't answer. Gabriel's body looks ravaged as he carefully steps closer and closer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabriel's legs suddenly SWING AROUND and SMACK Thomas, sprawling him back into the dirt. The iron bar goes flying as Gabriel in a flash is on top of him. Thomas thrashes but Gabriel easily pins his shoulders and sits on his chest. Without hurry he uncurls the fingers of his right hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas's eyes are wild with fear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabriel's spread fingers lower themselves toward his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabriel hesitates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gabriel's becoming unglued.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A shudder passes through Gabriel. He straightens up and looks down at Thomas as emotion racks his body.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The two stare at one another. Then Gabriel, lost in himself, suddenly turns away from Thomas and walks into the darkness. For the village. Thomas climbs quickly to his feet, spins around -- -- And is HIT full-force by a rabid, SHRIEKING Rachael. Her legs lock around his body vise-like as her teeth and nails DIG into his skin. He cries out and stumbles to the ground. The two grapple furiously in the dust, Rachel's crazed face taking BITE after BITE out of his shoulder and neck. Thomas manages a fistfull of her hair and YANKS the fangs off his shoulder. With his other arm he CUFFS her hard, BREAKING the grip and ROLLING her aside. He staggers to his knees and begins to run. Shrieking, a mad porcelain banshee out of the dusk, Rachael catches up and TACKLES him. On the way down his head strikes a small stone wall and the pain is white thunder. Gagging and weeping in blank shock, he crawls on his hands and knees as Rachael OPENS UP his arm from shoulder to elbow with her nails. As the blood tumbles like ribbons, Rachael JUMPS onto his back, DIGGING her claws into his scalp. It's about all one human can take. Mad with pain and anger and desperation, Thomas manages to climb to a shaky crouch, Rachael still shrieking on his back. Throwing all his weight backward, he JAMS her into the short stone wall. The impact SNAPS her hold and PROPELS her over the wall -- And two thousand feet down the side of the butte. Thomas Daggett can only curl up into a ball, gulping shallow, shuddering breaths.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You'll like this, Rachael.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (breathless) Nice move.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You ought to come work for us. Upstairs. We sneak the odd civilian in now and then, you know. You'd like it. Nobody tells you when to go to bed, can eat all the ice cream you want. And you get to kill. All day and all night. Just like an angel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Save yourself, friend. Why go to the wall with the bitch and her rug rat? It'll all turn out the same anyway. Here or in heaven, we're still gonna tear the kid apart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not an angel, heaven or hell. I'm a man you eyeless puke, which means I have one thing you never will. A soul. And though I may, somewhere inside, believe in a God, I will never, never, believe in you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A little speechy today, aren't we? (sighs) Okay pal, have it your way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is going to really, really hurt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...You -- your war...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: C'mon, son, out with it. Make this one count.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your war's a lie!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pauses) What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Running around acting like this is really about whether Christ is just the son of God or if he is God. Bullshit! That's not what this is about at all, is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're wrong.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then prove it to me, Gabriel. I studied three fucking years of theology before I picked up a gun. C'mon, you're chief goddamn angel, I'm just a little man. Prove to me Christ is just a son and less than God. Prove it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't have to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because you can't! Because this war isn't about some obscure medieval hangup. You're just jealous.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're wrong!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Try me, Gabriel. Go on. Prove to me the temporal nature of the Trinity. Show me through logic how the Son of the Word can be separated from the Father. Fight me with philosophy, Gabriel!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because you and your army are wrong! And you know it. You knew it sixteen centuries ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We don't have to listen to him! He's just a son!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's it. You're jealous. Jealous He could love something more than you...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hisses) Shut up...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you wanted to know so badly, Gabriel, why didn't you just ask Him? Why didn't you just ask God?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because He doesn't talk to us anymore!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Gabriel walks resolutely up to the first hogan and KICKS down the plank wood door. No one home. He walks to the second and KICKS its door down. Nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary's ceremony is nearing a crescendo. Grey Horse has donned the colorful mask of the yei god Monster Slayer as the relatives now join in the guttural chants of the Enemy Ghost Way. Through the thick, choking smoke of the ceremonial fire we see Katherine, nervously watching the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas tries hopelessly to make his way back. Stumbling every few steps, he's beyond pain and into driven numbness. It's hopeless though. We know it.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: IN THE DARKNESS OUTSIDE THE VILLAGE

direction.raw_text: Gabriel KICKS down another door to another empty hogan. There's only one left. As he approaches, from within can be heard the muffled sound of chanting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Takes a few more fumbling steps and falls again. He reaches out to something metal for support. It's Katherine's pickup.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steps up to the kiva door and KICKS it. The frame buckles but holds. He steps back a few feet, puts all his weight into a turn, and KICKS again. The door SHATTERS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wood splinters ROCKET through the smoke as Gabriel appears in the doorway. Grey Horse, everyone, freezes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From out of the smoke steps Katherine. She FIRES, one round, into Gabriel's side. The archangel is pitched against the kiva's wall, where he stays a moment before turning to Katherine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stands her ground between him and the child.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Once again, the shade of doubt holds him up. But it's quickly pushed aside for a corrupted grin. He's given up all pretense.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He advances on her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he's on her. With his left arm he brutally forces her to her knees as his right hand, palm out and fingers splayed, clamp themselves over her face. Katherine's mouth opens in a silent scream as the pain, immediate and beyond endurance, flows through her body. From somewhere outside, there's a sound. Katherine gulps chokes of agony as her very clothes begin to smolder around her. We hear the sound once more, closer, before -- The entire kiva wall EXPLODES INWARD as Katherine's pickup CRASHES through it. The mangled grill and hood SLAM into Gabriel from the side and SMASH him to the ground like a broken puppet. Katherine falls backward to the floor, gets up, and runs to the truck's cab. Inside sits a near catatonic Thomas. Katherine takes only a second to share a look with him before reaching back and pulling out the pickup's tire iron. Gabriel, a shattered, broken thing, pulls himself up to his knees. The sunglasses are gone and two eyeless pits stare out at Mary, huddled in the corner. Bleeding from every pore, one arm bent back the wrong way, he crawls across the floor toward her, his voice the milky slur of a stroke victim.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Katherine brings the tire iron down on his skull with all her might, DRIVING him to the floor. She turns to Grey Horse, her eyes wild.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He, everyone, just stare. Stunned to stone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grey Horse timidly picks up his prayer stick and with a voice faltering and cracked, in the insane glare of the wrecked pickup's headlights, resumes the Enemy Ghost Way chant. Katherine turns back to Gabriel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She HITS him again with the tire iron. Then lifts it high once more above her head. She's going to crush him, to implode his skull. When a hand stops her. Sort of a hand. A claw. Lucifer's. He's standing behind her, holding the raised bar still.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Katherine releases the bar and lets it clang to the floor. Lucifer turns to the villagers, gazing fearfully at him as they awkwardly try to finish the chant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lucifer's gaze falls on a deeply fucked-up Gabriel who groans at the sight of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lucifer kneels down beside him. Katherine instinctively starts to reach for the tire iron but the sycophant hisses a liquid, chattering warning at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lucifer slams Gabriel's head against the floor and pins it. As the angel thrashes furiously, Lucifer FORCES his arm into Gabriel's chest. Gabriel cries out as Lucifer PULLS his arm half out and FORCES it deeper. Again. And again. Soon Gabriel's screams become giggles, then a crazed, hysterical laughter. The room goes insane. An impossible nightmare of chanting Navahos, glaring headlights, and Gabriel's echoing laughter as Lucifer pumps his chest. Laughter that rises to a kind of orgasmic cry then instantly stops as Lucifer pulls out the angel's heart, And eats it. At that instant Grey Horse places his hand on Mary's forehead, speaks a last line, and the chant is completed. Sticky, smoky, awful silence. Gabriel is a non-thing. A battered, hollow shell. Bartholomew Grey Horse, his voice cracked and finished, turns to Katherine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From outside the kiva suddenly comes the sound of a wounded, savage GROWL. Katherine walks to the doorway. Just outside a lone coyote is twisting in the dirt with furious agony. Abruptly its thrashings cease. The animal stands and flashes for an instant at Katherine cold yellow eyes more than animal. Then it's gone into the blackness. Forever. She turns and goes back to Thomas in the cab. Bleeding to death is a real possibility for him. She pulls an old shirt out of the back and tries to makeshift a wrap for his sliced arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A few of the village elders appear at the cab.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Katherine walks over to where Mary, sweaty and shaken, sits huddled in a corner attended by Grey Horse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary's voice shakes as tears roll out her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Katherine gathers her up into her arms and holds her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The chattering, hissing sycophant grabs Gabriel's body by the hair and shoulders and drags it out the door. Lucifer has remained behind, crouched on his haunches, his liquid, yellow eyes on Katherine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He rises to his feet and steps slowly toward her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just a grinning, twisted stare.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The smallest hint of a pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he's gone. Through the door and into the night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : The fullness of day over Old Woman Butte, hot and bright. Chasing the night and its fears away under the punishing glare of noon. The village is full of police vehicles now. Green broncos from the Navaho Tribal Police. Blue and white sheriff department sedans. The Navaho cops are talking with Katherine and Mary. Thomas is sitting on the trunk of a patrol car getting his wounds properly bandaged as the Sheriff we met earlier leans beside him chewing on a wild oat stalk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He chews some more on his stalk. Looks off at the village.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Sheriff looks over at Katherine's pickup still jammed into the side of the kiva.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Sheriff takes his hat off. Runs his finger along the inside band.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Sheriff pushes off from the patrol car and tosses aside the oak stalk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The deputy finishes his bandaging.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He follows his boss. Katherine and Mary walk up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The moment drifts into silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her eyes settle on his.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She touches his cheek, Mary cradled between them.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Relax folks, it's just a soul.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm getting real tired of you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go to hell.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Heaven, darling. Heaven. At least get the zip code right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's all the same, isn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. In heaven we believe in love.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what do you love, Gabriel?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cracking your skull.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's all it is for you anymore, Gabriel, isn't it? Just the killing and the burning. You don't work for God anymore. You don't fight for love.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shut up!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: God loves you, Mary!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Finish it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Finish it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please. Go on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh man, this just isn't my day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Long time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The world's young, man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And full of ambition.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This isn't your war.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I remember the last one. Michael's war.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You lost.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But lots of angels were with me. every one followed their leader out of heaven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah yeah, I was there, remember?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Except one. Oh, he was with me all right. He hated the Eagle Scout. Envied the power He gave to His Son. But this angel never came out front during the war. And when it ended he thought maybe, maybe the Eagle Scout didn't notice. So he laid low and towed the company line till he could start his own war. It was all just jealousy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're dreaming.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But maybe He did notice. Maybe that's why I'm here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stay away from me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've always been a part of me, Gabriel. And now it's time to come home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fuck you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The enemy spirit is gone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (weak, faint) Where?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: More will come... To look for the soul...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And they won't find it. Not in Mary.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can you help him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We have some bandages.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you all right, pumpkin?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's going to be okay... We're all going to be okay...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't quite bring myself to say thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I understand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then this is done.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not necessarily. Maybe I like you. Maybe I want you to come with me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You owe me, Katherine. And you're going to ask me to take you home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (clutching Mary) No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You will. You will because any other way is going to be more awful than you can imagine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you threatening me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then you've picked the wrong person this time. I've just about had it up to here with ghosts. So you can put away the horror movie sneer and the K-Mart halloween eyes, because we know you now. We know you all. And if you want to force the issue then go ahead because you're just another angel to me. Take a look at your buddy Gabriel. Then ask yourself, do you really, really want to fuck with us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Perhaps another time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm holding my breath.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodbye, Katherine. For now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is he coming back?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think so, honey... I don't think so...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to deputy bandaging Thomas) Is he going to live?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: With any luck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Thomas) I thought I told you to give me a call if anything snarled.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There wasn't a phone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hmmm.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This fella, Gabriel...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gabriel what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just Gabriel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pretty violent guy, Gabriel. Even for out here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Caught up with him at the village?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He caught up with me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What were you doing way up here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Enemy Ghost Way for Mary Tsosie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Indian stuff.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. Indian stuff.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you kill this Gabriel?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe. I think so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't have any idea where the body is I suppose.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, if he's alive he won't get far out there. Us or the coyotes, it'll be the same. (beat) I rang your office in LA. They don't have a warrant out for a Gabriel. Or anybody else in Arizona.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hadn't gotten around to it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sort of an out of pocket thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That woman lying at the bottom of the arroyo, the one still in her hospital gown, know anything about that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This Gabriel was sure one busy dude.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, he was.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll be going back to Los Angeles now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't hurry back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't do much but breathe the next few days. And get to a hospital. You're going to need some serious stitches.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Say hi to Hollywood for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You look bad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you. I feel worse. (to Katherine re Navaho cops) They lean on you much?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not really. I think they might have even understood. One of them's related to this clan. He'll give us a ride back if we want.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good. I think I've about run out of hospitality with the sheriff's department.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you think it's really over?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Till we die.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When I die, I want you with me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want that too.
dialogue.name: dialogue
